titleStmt.title: A booke, containing the true portraiture of the countenances and attires of the kings of England, from William Conqueror, vnto our Soueraigne Lady Queene Elizabeth now raigning together with a briefe report of some of the principall acts of the same kings, especially such as haue bene least mentioned in our late writers. Diligently collected by T.T.
titleStmt.author: Talbot, Thomas, antiquary.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 31 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 24 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. notesStmt.note: Attributed to Thomas Talbot (STC addendum). Also sometimes attributed to Thomas Tymme and to Thomas Twyne.
Same item identified as both STC 23626 and 24415 on UMI microfilm.
Reproduction of a photostat of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A BOOKE, CONTAINING THE TRVE PORTRAITVRE OF THE COVNTENANCES and attires of the kings of England, from William Conqueror, vnto our Soueraigne Lady Queene Elizabeth now raigning:
TOGETHER WITH A BRIEFE report of ≈øome of the principall acts of the ≈øame Kings, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as haue bene lea≈øt mentioned in our late writers.
Diligently collected by T. T.
LONDON Printed by Iohn de Beauche≈øne dwelling in the Blacke Fryers. 1597.

WILLIAM, Duke of Normandy, ba≈øe ≈øonne of Robert Duke of Normandy, being a warlike & politick prince, of neere kinred, & great credit with Edward Confe≈ø≈øor king of England (whom he perceiued more giueÃÑ to vertue theÃÑ to pollicy, & through weaknes of body, & cour≈øe of yeares, vnlikely to liue long) began to contriue in his mynd, the attaining of the crowne of this land after the decea≈ø≈øe of the old king. For accoÃÑpli≈øhing whereof, he placed diuer≈øe Normans in the greate≈øt roomes about him while≈øt he liued, and when he was dead, leuied an army of ≈øundry nations, and therewith pretending the patronage of England again≈øt Harolde the ≈øonne of Godwin, that v≈øurped the kingdome, fir≈øt fought with him & ≈ølue him, at the place now called Batell in Su≈ø≈øex, the xiiij. of October, in the yeare 1066. tooke the crowne vpon him by election of the E≈øtates. Then ≈øeeking to ≈øtop titles, he impri≈øoned Eadgar Etheling, the only true heire of the Saxons bloud, & by meanes of Ethelbert Archbi≈øhop of Hamborow for money, procured Suene king of Denmarke to ≈øurcea≈øe the clame of the Danes. Hauing thus e≈øtabli≈øhed his affairs died at S. Geruis neare Roane the 9. of Sept. an. 1087. when he had raigned xx. yeares, x. moneths, and xxvj. dayes, and was buried at Cane, in the abbey of S. Stephen, which he founded.

WILLIAM Rufus third ≈øonne to the Conqueror, borne in Normandy long before his father obtayned the realme, hearing of his death made ha≈øt into England (lea≈øt by his elder brother Robert he ≈øhould be preuented) was by his large gifts, which he be≈øtowed out of his fathers trea≈øurie, hauing obtayned the keyes thereof, receiued of the Nobility, accepted of the inferior ≈øort, to be their king, but chiefly by the per≈øwa≈øion of the archbi≈øhop Lanfranke, vnder whom he was brought vp, and was by him crowned at VVe≈øtmin≈øter the xxvij. day of October, anno 1087. He was brought vp with great care of his parents, obeying his father in all his actions, wherefore his father at his death appointed him to ≈øucceede in the kingdome. He vanqui≈øhed the VVel≈øhmen, ouercame the Scots, and ≈øubdued his two vncles, and others of his Nobility that rebelled again≈øt him in the behalfe of his elder brother, Robert Duke of Normandy. He was ≈ølaine with an arrowe as he was hunting in the new fore≈øt in Ham≈øhire, by a knight of his, called Sir Walter Tirel, the fir≈øt day of Augu≈øt an. 1100 when he had raigned xiij. yeares, lacking xxij. dayes, and was buried at Winche≈øter.

HENRIE Beauclarke, fourth ≈øonne to the Conqueror, was cho≈øen king after the buriall of his brother, by meanes of his old familiar friend, Henrie Earle of Warwicke, although there was ≈øome controuer≈øie among≈øt the Nobilitie about the ≈øame, yet the rather they con≈øented thereto, becau≈øe he was by birth both an Engli≈øhman, & ≈øonne to a King and Queene, for he was borne in England the third yeare of his fathers raigne. He was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the fift day of Augu≈øt by Maurice Bi≈øhop of London, in the ab≈øence of the Archbi≈øhop An≈øelme. In the ≈øeueÃÑth yeare of his raigne he tooke his elde≈øt brother Robert Duke of Normandy pri≈øoner, and ≈øo he kept him till he dyed. After which time he called him≈øelfe King of England, & Duke of Normandy. He left behind him but one onely daughter lawfully begotten, Maud the Empre≈ø≈øe, then maried to Geffrey Plantaginet Earle of Angio, mother to King Henry the ≈øecoÃÑd. He died at S. Denis in the fore≈øt of Lions in Normandie, the fir≈øt day of December, anno 1135. when he had raigned xxxv. yeares and foure moneths, & was buried in the Abbey of Reding, which he had founded.

STEPHEN borne in France, and brought vp in England vnder his vncle king Henry the fir≈øt, Erle of Mortain, & in right of Maud his wife Erle of Bolein, third ≈øonne of Stephen Erle of Champaine and Blais, and Alice his wife, daughter to William Conqueror king of England, began his raigne ouer this realme the ij. day of December, anno 1135. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the xxvj. day of the ≈øame month by the hands of William Corbuell archbi≈øhop of Canterbury. This king came to the crowne by v≈øurpation, and periurie both of him≈øelf & mo≈øt part of the Bi≈øhops and Nobilitie (both he and they being before that ≈øworne to maintaine the right of Maud the Empre≈ø≈øe and her i≈ø≈øue) for the which God iu≈øtly ≈øent this plague of di≈ø≈øention & rebellion amoÃÑg≈øt them, which neuer could be appea≈øed during his raigne. He was valiant and hardie, for in a battell at Lincolne, where all his Nobility were fled or taken, he valiantly ≈øtood in the forward continually fighting, be≈øtowing ≈øuch ≈øtroks as tho≈øe whoÃÑ he hit, were either rewarded with death, or neuer pro≈øpered after. He died in Kent the 25. of October, 1154. hauing raigned 18. yeares, 9. moneths, and 23. daies, & was buried at Feuer≈øham. After who≈øe death there was interregnum 54. dayes.

HENRIE ≈øurnamed Fitz Emprice, borne in Mayne, ≈øonne of Geffrey Plantaginet Earle of Angio & Maud the Empres daughter and heire to Henrie the fir≈øt, king of England, being of the age of xx. yeres, began his raign ouer this realme the xix. of December, 1154. and was crowned the ≈øame day at We≈øtmin≈øter. This king in right of his father vnited the Earledome of Angio to the crowne of England: & the Dukedome of Aquitaine, with the Earldom of Poitiers in right of Alianore his wife, & by coÃÑque≈øt ≈øubdued the Duchy of Britaine, & the kingdome of Ireland therunto. So that he was the only Monarch and chiefe gouernor froÃÑ the Iles of Orcades beyond Scotland, vnto the vttermo≈øt bonds of the mountaines Perines, which deuide France & Spaine. He was the fir≈øt that ordained the Iu≈øtice of Ayer, & for the ea≈øe of the people he deuided this land into ≈øixe circuits, appointing to euery one 3. Iudges, well learned in the lawes of this land. He ended his dayes at Chinon in France the vj. day of Iuly, ann. 1189. when he had raigned 34. yeares, 7. months, lacking ten daies, and was buried at Fount Euerard. After who≈øe death there was interregnum for the ≈øpace of lviij. dayes.

RICHARD Erle of Poitiers, born at Oxford, ≈øecond ≈øonne of king Henry the ij. being xxxv. yeares old began his raign ouer this realm the 3. of Septemb. 1189. & was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the ≈øame day, by Baldwin Archbi≈øhop of CaÃÑ terbury. He taking his iourney toward the holy laÃÑd, was mi≈øu≈øed by the way of the CipriaÃÑs, wherat he being offended, ≈øet vpon them, ≈øubdued theÃÑ, & in xv. dayes conquered the whole Iland, tooke the Emperour therof, & kept him in fetters of ≈øiluer. FroÃÑ thence he took his iourney to the ≈øiege of Acon, where he mo≈øt valiantly behaued him≈øelf, ≈øo that his only name was a terror to the Turkes. After this, by rea≈øon of rebellion of his brother Iohn, & inua≈øion of his territories beyoÃÑd the ≈øeas by the king of France, was forced to return home and was taken by the way & impri≈øoned by Leopoldus Duke of Au≈øtria, who≈øe enuie was great again≈øt him, becau≈øe in his youth he had ≈ølain the Dukes brother with a che≈ø≈øe boord in the Court of France, as they played together. This king be≈øieging the Ca≈øtle of Chalut, was ≈øtriken with a venimed quarell, whereof he died the 6. of April, 1199. hauing raigned 9. yeares, 7. moneths, and three dayes, and lyeth at Fount Euerard. After who≈øe death there was interregnum 21. dayes.

IOHN Lord of Ireland, Erle of Mortain & Glouce≈øter, brother to the late king Richard 1. & younge≈øt ≈øonne of king Henry the ij. being of the age of xxxij. yeares, began his raigne ouer this realme the xxvij. of Aprill, 1199. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the ≈øame day. This king was the fir≈øt that did write him≈øelf Lord of Ireland: which continued in his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, vntill king Henry the 8. the 21. of Ianuary, in the 33. yere of his raign wrote him≈øelf king of Ireland. This king tooke, impri≈øoned, & put to death his nephew Arthur Duke of Britaine, ≈øonne & heire to Geffrey Duke of Britain, third ≈øonne to king Henry the ij. right heire to the crowne: & kept Alianore his ≈øi≈øter in pri≈øon, becau≈øe ≈øhe ≈øhould neither marrie nor haue i≈ø≈øue: wherefore Philip the French king cited him ≈øundrie times to appeare before him which he refu≈øed to do: & was therefore adiudged by his Peeres of France to forfait all his lands which he held of the crowne of France. He died in the Ca≈øtle of Newarke the 19. of October, anno 1216. when he had raigned 17. yeares, 5. moneths, and 23. dayes, and lyeth at Worce≈øter. After who≈øe death there was interregnum for the ≈øpace of 8. dayes.

HENRY the third, ≈øonne & heire to king Iohn, being 9. yeares old beganne his raigne ouer this realme the 28. day of Octob. 1216. & was crowned the ≈øame day at Glouce≈øter by the hands of Peter bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter. This king brought into this land & preferred to great dignities his halfe brethren by the mother, ≈øons of Hugh de Brun Erle of March, whereby they grew ≈øo in≈øolent & proud that they di≈ødained all the Engli≈øh Nobilitie, which was the fir≈øt occa≈øion & beginning of the great rebellioÃÑ called the Barons wars, wherein many thou≈øand Engli≈øh men lo≈øt their liues, be≈øide the di≈øinheriting of ≈øome of the chiefe≈øt of the Nobility for euer. This king in the 44. yeare of his raign pa≈ø≈øed ouer ≈øea into FraÃÑce, & concluded a league, wherin it was agreed that the king of England ≈øhould ≈øurcea≈øe the claime of all his lands in France, except only Aquitain, whereupon he and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors vntill the xiiij. yeare of Edward the third, wrote theÃÑ≈øelues kings of England, Lords of Ireland, and Dukes of Aquitaine. He died the xvj. of Nouember, anno, 1272. when he had raigned 56. yeares, and 20. dayes, and was buried at We≈øtmin≈øter. After who≈øe death there was interregnum for 3. daies.

EDWARD the fir≈øt, King of England, ≈øonne of king Henry the third, at his fathers decea≈øe warred again≈øt the Infidels in the holy laÃÑd, and began his raigne the xx. day of Nouember anno 1272. was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter by Robert Kilwardby Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie, the xviij. day of September in the ≈øecond yeare of his raigne. By his fir≈øt marriage he encrea≈øed his inheritance in France, with the Earledome of Ponthiou. By his conque≈øt he enlarged his kingdome at home with the principalitie of Wales, which he be≈øtowed vpoÃÑ his elde≈øt ≈øonne, and began the cu≈øtome of the kings of England to create their elde≈øt ≈øonnes princes of Wales. He reformed the extortion of his officers, and chiefly of them which had the admini≈øtration of Iu≈øtice. He e≈øtabli≈øhed lawes for the pre≈øeruation of his owne e≈øtate, e≈øpecially that of Mortmane again≈øt donations to religious hou≈øes: that of Quia emptores terrarum, again≈øt alienatioÃÑ without licence, & that of Quo warranto again≈øt v≈øurpation of royall iuri≈ødictions & liberties. He died at Burgh vpon the Sands, the vij. day of Iuly, anno 1307. when he had raigned xxxiiij. yeares, vij. moneths, & xviij. dayes, & lieth at We≈øtmin≈øter.

EDWARD the ≈øecond, borne at Carnaruon in Northwales, ≈øonne to King Edward the fir≈øt, began his raigne ouer this realme the 8. day of Iuly, in the yeare of our Lord 1307. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter by the Bi≈øhoppe of Winche≈øter, deputy for Robert Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie then ab≈øent in exile, the xxiiij. of February next en≈øuing. He was much giuen to follow the adui≈øe and coun≈øell of light per≈øons, which cau≈øed the Nobility to rebell again≈øt him, but at the fir≈øt he ouercame them, and tooke Thomas Earle of Lanca≈øter their chiefe Captaine, and ≈øate in iudgement him≈øelfe on him at Pontfret, where the ≈øame Earle had ≈øentence giuen again≈øt him, to be drawne for his trea≈øon, for his murther, ≈øpoile, burning and robberies, to be hanged, and for his ≈øhamefull flying away, to be beheaded: but becau≈øe he was of the kings linage, he was onely beheaded. At the la≈øt ≈øuch of the Barons as before e≈øcaped, and chiefly the Mortimers with helpe of the Queene and the young Prince, then new come out of France, tooke the King, and impri≈øoned him, when he had raigned xix. yeares, ≈øixe monethes, and ≈øeuenteene dayes.

EDWARD the third, ≈øonne to Edward ij. began his raigne ouer this realme the xxv. day of Ianuary, ann. 1327. his father yet liuing & in pri≈øon, & was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter on the i. of February following This king created his elde≈øt ≈øonne Edward Duke of Cornwall (which was the fir≈øt Duke that was created in England ≈øince the Conque≈øt) & ordeined that the kings elde≈øt ≈øons euer after ≈øhould be Dukes of Cornewall. He largely augmented the wages of the Iudges of both benches, & barons of th'exchequer, and allowed theÃÑ three robes euery yeare, becau≈øe they ≈øhould not take fees or rewards of any but onely of the king, ≈øo that they ≈øhould be the better able to mini≈øter iu≈øtice to euery man without affection, & puni≈øhed the offenders herein mo≈øt ≈øeuerly. For he cau≈øed Sir WilliaÃÑ Thorp knight chiefe Iu≈øtice of the kings bench, to be arrained for taking of money (contrary to his oth) of certaine per≈øons coÃÑuict before him at Lincoln, for felony, to deferre their execution, & being fouÃÑd guilty, had ≈øentence to be hanged, & to forfeit his lands & goods to the king. He died at Shene, the 21. of Iune, 1377. hauing raigned 50. yeares and fiue moneths, lacking 4. daies, & lieth at We≈øtmin≈øt.

RICHARD the ≈øecond king of England, borne at Bordeaux, ≈øonne to Edward the blacke Prince, being xi. yeares old, began his raigne the xxij. day of Iune, anno 1377. & was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the xvj. day of Iuly next en≈øuing, by the hands of Simon Theobald Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury. This king was comely of per≈øonage, and in bountifulne≈ø≈øe and liberalitie farre pa≈ø≈øed all his progenitors, much more giuen to re≈øt then to mar≈øhall affaires, folowing the fanta≈øie of flatterers and yong heads, neglecting the Nobilitie, which was cau≈øe of rebellion in the beginning of his raigne, of great ≈øtrife among the Nobilitie in the mid≈øt, & the ouerthrow & vtter de≈øtruction of him≈øelfe in the latter end. He was the fir≈øt that created any to the dignity of a Marquis in this realme of England. He al≈øo created Margaret daughter and heire to Thomas of Brotherton Earle of Norfolke and Mar≈øhall of England, Duches of Norfolke. He was at the la≈øt for≈øaken of his friends, taken & put in pri≈øon by Henry Bolinbroke, ≈øonne and heire to Iohn of Gaunt, Duke of Lanca≈øter, who ≈øucceeded him. He raigned 22. yeares, three moneth, & 9. daies, and was buried at Langeley.

HENRY the fourth, borne at Bollingbroke in Lincoln≈øhire, Duke of Hereford, ≈øon and heire to Iohn of Gaunt Duke of Lanca≈øter, being bani≈øhed by king Richard the ij. after the death of his father, entred England in Holdernes, fir≈øt made claime onely to the Duchie of Lanca≈øter, being his fathers inheritance, after hauing augmented his power, by fal≈øe and ≈øini≈øter ≈øurmi≈øes claimed the crowne of England, ≈øet vpon the king, tooke and impri≈øoned him, where he mo≈øt mi≈øerably ended his life: began his raigne ouer this Realme the xxx. day of September, an. 1399. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the xiij. day of October following by the hands of Thomas Arundell Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury. This king in the beginning of his raigne was much troubled with ciuill wars, and al≈øo with inua≈øion both of the Frenchmen & Scots, but yet at the length he (through Gods helpe) obtained the victory ouer all his enemies, and liued in great quietne≈ø≈øe with loue of his ≈øubiects all the 1 e≈øt of his raigne. He died at We≈øtmin≈øter the xx. of March, anno 1413. when he had raigned xiij. yeares, and ≈øixe moneths lacking x. daies. And was honourablie buried at Canterbury.

HENRY the fift, borne at Monemouth, in the Marches of Wales, ≈øonne of king Henry the fourth, began his raigne ouer this realme the xxj. day of March, in the yeare of our Lord 1413. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the ix. day of Aprill following by the hands of Thomas Arundell Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury. On the which day there was a terrible tempe≈øt of ≈ønow, to the great admiration of all tho≈øe that were pre≈øent. He was tall of bodie, and very ≈øtrong, giuen altogether together to mar≈øhall affaires, and a mortall enemie to idlene≈ø≈øe, as it plainly appeareth by his great conque≈øts. In the beginning of his raigne he was troubled with dome≈øticall rebellion, in the mid≈øt with warres in France, but in the latter end, concluding a perpetuall league with Charles the French king, maried his daughter, was made heire and regent of France, and ≈øo in all his ≈øtiles was written vntill his dying day. He ended his life at Boys Vincent by Paris the fir≈øt day of September, betweene two & three of the clocke in the morning, in the yeare of our Lord 1422. when he had raigned nine yeares, fiue moneths, and eleuen daies, and was buried at We≈øtmin≈øter.

HENRIE the ≈øixt, borne at Winde≈øore, ≈øonne of king Henry the fift, being of the age of viij. moneths, began his raigne ouer this realme the i. day of September, in the yeare of our Lord 1422. and was crowned fir≈øt at We≈øtmin≈øter the vi. of Nouember 1429. by the hands of Henry Chicheley Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie, and afterward the vij. day of September, anno 1431. at Paris by the hands of Henry Beauford Cardinall of Winche≈øter. This king was the fir≈øt that erected any to the dignitie of a Vicount in this land, or that created any Barron by charter or pattent: for before his daies all Barrons were either made in the field, or called to that ≈øtate by Parliament writ. He was farre more fitter for the Church, then for cheualrie, for prayer, then for prowe≈ø≈øe, a man mo≈øt vnfortunate in all his worldly attempts, he lo≈øt not only all that his father won in France, but al≈øo his owne kingdome here at home, for he was at the la≈øt in the xxxix. yeare of his raigne driuen out of his kingdome, and after that, taken and put in pri≈øon, where he mo≈øt mi≈øerably ended his life. Hee raigned xxxviij. yeares, ≈øixe moneths, and ≈øoure dayes, and was buried fir≈øt at Cherte≈øey, and after remoued to Wind≈øore.

EDWARD Earle of March, borne at Roane in Normandie, ≈øonne and heire to Richard Duke of Yorke, ≈øonne to Richard Earle of Cambridge, ≈øonne to Edmund of Langley Duke of Yorke, fourth ≈øonne to Edward the iij. king of England, begaÃÑ his raigne ouer this realme (by the name of king Edward the fourth, the fourth day of March anno 1461. & was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the xxix. day of Iune next following by the hands of Thomas Bourghchier Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie. He was al≈øo troubled with warres again≈øt the Scots. But hauing brought all things both at home & abroad to quietne≈ø≈øe, he began to waxe idle and couetous, which was not only cau≈øe of much grudge among≈øt the people, but al≈øo of ≈øhortening of his daies. He ended his life at We≈øtmin≈øter the 9. day of Aprill, in the yeare of our Lord 1483. when he had raigned xxij. yeares, one moneth, and v. daies, and was honorably buried at Wind≈øore.

EDWARD the fift, borne in the ≈øanctuary at We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øonne of king Edward the fourth, began his raigne ouer this realme the tenth day of Aprill, in the yeare of our Lord 1483. being of the age of thirteene yeares, but by the cunning dealing of Richard Duke of Glouce≈øter his vnnaturall vncle, was neuer crowned, although there was great preparatioÃÑ made for the ≈øame: for his vncle at the fir≈øt taking vpon him to be protector and gouernor both of the child and the realme, after that defaming him, and all his other brethren and ≈øi≈øters to be ba≈øtards, impri≈øoned and executed mo≈øt part of his friends, and procured the younger brother, Richard Duke of Yorke and Norfolk to be fetched out of the ≈øanctuarie at We≈øtmin≈øter, and put them both in the towre of London, from whence they neuer departed, but were there mo≈øt lamentably murdered, by the procurement of their cruell vncle. RICHARD Duke of Glouce≈øter, younge≈øt brother to king Edward the fourth, began his v≈øurped raigne ouer this realme by the name of k. Richard the third, the xxij. day of Iune, an. 1483. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the vj. day of Iuly next en≈øuing. He not contented with the depo≈øing of his nephews from their right, nor thinking him≈øelfe ≈øurely ≈øetled in the kingdome, till he had bere≈øt them of their liues, cau≈øed the great ≈øeale of England to be fetched from Iohn Ru≈ø≈øell bi≈øhop o. Lincolne, Lord Chauncellour, being at London, & brought vnto him, being on his progre≈ø≈øe then in Warwick≈øhire, wherewith he ≈øecretly ≈øealed ≈øuch commi≈ø≈øions as ≈øerued to the murder of the two ≈øweet babes. And theÃÑ ≈øent the ≈øeale backe againe to the Chauncellor, after it had bin viij. dayes in his cu≈øtody. HENRIE Earle of Richmond, borne in Penbroke ca≈øtle in Wales, ≈øonne of Edmund of Hadham Earle of Richmond, ≈øonne of Owen ap Meredeth, and Queene Katherine the French kings daughter, late wife to king Henry the fift, being of the age of xxx. yeares, began his raigne ouer this realme, by the name of king Henry the vij. the xxij. day of Augu≈øt, anno 1485. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the xxx. day of October next en≈øuing, by the hands of Thomas Bourghchier Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury. EDWARD the ≈øixt, borne at Hampton Court, ≈øonne & heire to king Henry the viij. being of the age of ix. years, began his raigne ouer this realme the xxviij. of Ianuary, 1547. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the xx. of Februarie next following, by the hands of Thomas Cranmer Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie. This king in his tender age ≈øo profited in all kind of vertue & good learning, that he attained to the perfect knowledge of the Greeke, Latine, and French tongs. MARIE borne at Grenewich, elder daughter to king Henry the viij. and ≈øi≈øter and heire to the late decea≈øed king Edward the vi. being of the age of xxxviij. yeares, began her raigne ouer this realme the vj. of Iuly, anno 1553. and was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the 1. of October next following, by the hands of Stephen Gardiner bi≈øhoppe of VVinche≈øter and Chauncellor of England: for Thomas Cranmer Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury was then pri≈øoner in the Tower. After this the lo≈ø≈øe of Caleis ≈øo troubled her, as the memorie thereof would neuer out of her mind till her dying day: ≈øo that ≈øhortly after ≈øhe died at her man≈øion hou≈øe called S. Iames neare to We≈øtmin≈øter the xvij. of Nouember, 1558. at iiij. of the clocke in the morning, hauing raigned v. yeares, v. moneths, and x. dayes, and was buried at We≈øtmin≈øter.

ELIZABETH our gracious Queene, born at Grenewich, ≈øecond daughter to king Henrie the viij. ≈øi≈øter & heire to the late Queene Marie, being of the age of 25. yeares, and two moneths, begaÃÑ her mo≈øt pro≈øperous raigne ouer this realm the xvij. of Nouember, 1558. & was crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter the xv. of Ianuarie next following, by the hands of OweÃÑ Oglethorp bi≈øhop of Carlile. She is a Prince≈ø≈øe adorned with all good litterature, both holy and humane, a nouri≈øher of peace both at home and abroad. Among≈øt all other her mo≈øt rare vertues, ≈øhe hath reformed religion, ≈øhe hath reduced all ba≈øe coines (which were currant here before her dayes) into perfect gold & ≈øiluer, ≈øo that there is no other mony le≈ø≈øe or more curraÃÑt within her dominions: which is not to be ≈øeene at this day el≈øe where vnder any Prince Chri≈øtian or Ethnicke.
